name: Peter Andre Saliva Tree by Peter James Field
description:
An amazing print, folded into a concertina book, made to accompany an exhibition at KK Outlet, London in 2011. The print connects Peter Andre, via marriages, divorces, affairs and offspring, to 250 famous people - this is actually an abridged version of the original which included a staggering 400 famous people.

Peter James Field is an illustrator based in Brighton, UK. 

folds out to approx 156 cm
folded, 19.5 x 29cm
b/w with black & red cover
Limited edition

name: Dieselbrugger Apokalypse by Emanuel Halpern
description:
When someone as peaceful as Swiss artist Emanuel Halpern (born 1948) draws an apocalypse, things must be pretty bad with the world. Inspired by Friedrich Dürrenmatt, Halpern has created 50 large-scale coloured pencil drawings that comically narrate the destruction of Dieselbrugg. Bold and graphic, this illustrated book presents a dark but colourful view of a modern world gone topsy-turvy.

In the Dieselbrugg Apocalypse, Halpern manages to move between pilgrimage and the misery of refugees with the sure-footedness of a somnambulist. "You can‘t really be as dozy as that" he seems to be muttering. "Come into my yurt In here you will hear peace bells ringing, you‘ll see bathing towels fluttering. This is Dieselbrugg." - Guido Magnaguagno 

Published by Nieves, 2010

56 pages
22 x 30 cm
Hardcover
Bilingual German + English
Colour Offset
First Edition

name: Proper Magazine issue 13
description:
'Focusing on a broad range of subjects, the seeds for Proper Magazine were sown as a homegrown fanzine more than 5 years ago. Now it’s all grown up, just like the people who read it'.

Issue 13 has surfing as its focus, it's a real delve into the surfing subculture, with both historical and contemporary coverage to set you on your way to summertime. With additional features on Our Legacy, adidas, Hawaiian shirts and a superb exclusive interview with Andrew Weatherall. 

96 pages
15 x 21 cm
full colour

name: MUSEUMS IV - Various
description:
Museums Press is an independent publishing house based in Glasgow, UK, founded in June 2009. 

MUSEUMS IV is the fifteenth Museums Press release and the fourth in a line of multi-part, compilation style packages. MP have teamed up with Comfortable on a Tightrope to curate a box which contains some of the best artists, musicians and practitioners the world has to offer.

It contains...

- Three x A5 photocopied group zines containing works by Tim Danko, Meryl Olah, Hether Fortune, Hayden Schiebler, Katie Miller, Quentin Szuwarski, Marvin de deus Ganhitas, Meghan Remy, Jess Scott, Clay Hickson, Jack Felgate, Ricardo Passaporte, Mitchell Cunmmings, Sun Foot and Antoine Aillot. 
- An A5 riso zine by Cali Thornhill Dewitt.
- An A4 single colour riso print by Nick Lynch.
- An A3 two colour riso print by Sonnenzimmer.
- Two full colour 1" badges by David Roeder.
- A mounted but removable single color riso cover postcard by Emma Balkind and Joe Howe.
- A 90 minute compilation tape cassette featuring music by Nisennenmondai, U.S. Girls, Sea Pinks, La Sera, Mikal Cronin, Mike Bones, Hannah Lew, La La Vasquez, Sun Foot, Sic Alps, Fear of Men, Sex Hands, Lexie Mountain, Olympus, Crazy Band, Moscow Chikuonki, Sonny Smith, Way Through, Brute Heart, They, Apostille, Meddicine, Keel Her, Tom Settle, Irma Vep, Wax Idols & Thanksgiving.
- Two photocopied inserts, one with art annotation and one with music annotation.

Published by Museums Press, 2012
Edition of 75

name: The Alarmist issue 2
description:
The Alarmist is a fresh, new, dark, funny and twisted printed literary magazine published biannually, based in the UK.

'It’s not about trying to prove how clever or well-read you are. We’re not the Paris Review. We want to buck the modern trend, and tickle and entertain with what we publish' - The Alarmist

“Plenty of variety, freedom, fun, irreverence, and ever-expanding talent… …Beautifully designed, with a strong graphic palette full of energy, it looks very nice, but is also filled with excellent and highly engaging written work '' - Itsnicethat.com

Poems, stories, essays, musings and beautiful artwork & illustrations. Featuring insects, fish, birds, dogs, pigs, reptiles, vegetables, aliens, dead lab assistants, natural disaster, ironic moral decay and so much more.

96 pages
17 x 24 cm
full colour

name: The Ride Journal Issue 7
description:
The Ride is a journal filled with personal stories. 'We know that most people who share our obsession with bikes don’t want to be pigeon-holed as roadies, freeriders, track racers, BMXers, XC riders or even commuters. They are just riders. So we wanted to create something for them, and also for us. Something that crosses both cycling and international borders. Bikes have changed people’s lives in so many ways and we wanted to gather a small selection of
these tales' - The Ride website.

194 pages
19.5 x 25.5cm
full colour

name: Connected Line Studies by Rob Lowe
description:
Connected Line Studies is an exploration of the optical effects of monochromatic connected lines.
 
Each image uses lines of the same thickness but varies the tone from black to light grey. Depending on the colour
and placement of the lines the optical effect differs greatly and can be altered by shifting focus, making the viewer an integral part of the artwork.
 
Rob Lowe, also known as Supermundane, is an artist, graphic designer, typographer and occasional poet. Born in the Midlands of England in 1971, his mesmeric abstract drawings have been published and exhibited worldwide. He lives and works in London, England.

Published by Mono No Aware, 2012

24 pages
15 x 21 cm
softcover
b/w

name: Botanica by Sander Meisner
description:
Sander Meisner was born in 1979 and currently lives and works in Amsterdam. Wandering through the edges of our cities, looking for colour and beauty in the desolate corners of grey, man-made structures, he photographs the (sleeping) infrastructure of the urban environment.

'Over the past four years I have been photographing trees and foliage at night. But I didn’t index out with this aim. I was working on images of buildings for another series and found these plants and trees in the course of that work and shot them for my own pleasure.'

Published by The Velvet Cell, 2012

52 pages
23 x 28 cm
Perfect Bound with Dust Jacket
Colour Offset
Limited Edition of 500

ISBN 9781908889003

name: Limner Journal Issue 2
description:
Limner is a new critical journal of illustration, aiming to provide a platform for the exploration, critique and contextualisation of contemporary illustration, to promote interesting and intelligent illustration and initiate a discourse into wider issues related to the industry, education and social impact (or lack thereof).

Issue 2 features work and words from Jordan Chatwin, Blaise Larmee, Colin David Stewart, Peter Willis, Penny Klein, Murray O'Grady, Stine Belden Røed, Grace Helmer, Jay Cover, Holly Mills, Reena Makwana, Kai Nodland, Reuben Mwaura & Joe Kessler, Liv Taylor, Eric Timothy Carlson, Charlotte Mei, Umberto Eco, Ella McLean, Florence Shaw, Hayley English, Nick White, Alice Lindsay, Matthew Walkerdine & Jessica Higgins, Joakim Ojanen, Mike Redmond & Jon Pilkington, Chie Miyazaki, Lisa Wilkens, Rose Blake, Megan Woof, Dan Shapiro, Isabella Toledo

168 pages
12cm x 17cm
full colour
open-sewn book

name: Indoor Living by Ryan Stewart Nault
description:
'Indoor Living PART ONE: GETTING ACQUAINTED'

Ryan Stewart Nault is an artist currently based in Chicago but originally from Michigan. His paintings often incorporate sculptural and everyday elements (t-shirts, plants, gloves), with a tonality akin to modern American painting, the likes of Edward Hopper et al, described by Ryan as harbouring the effects of 'domestic comfort'. This book collates a series of realistic paintings as well as abstract sketches based around ideas of solitary living and getting to know ones own surroundings.

Indoor Living, Part One: Getting Acquainted is the first in a series of developing publications by this extremely exciting young painter.

Published by Museums Press, 2012

28 pages
21.6cm x 28cm
full colour
saddle sticthed 
first edition of 100

name: British Folk Pt 2 by James Pearson Howes
description:
The second in a trilogy documenting the strange and bizarre folk traditions that still go on in Britain today. Part Two is a celebration of British eccentricity, rooted in ancient traditions. These traditions are a powerful cohesive force for the communities that keep them alive.

The second book concentrates on the Pearly Kings and Queens of London, the Cornish ‘Obby ‘Oss and Lewes Bonfire night.

The Pearly Kings and Queens are arguably the most visually compelling of London’s folk traditions. This section of the book focuses on the larger-than-life personalities that uphold this tradition. The surreal, intensely rooted ‘Obby ‘Oss festival is fiercely guarded by the local residents of Padstow. This provides a rare glimpse into this event. The last section of the book captures the local characters who form one of the original Lewes bonfire night societies. These societies create and stage this anarchic, theatrical spectacle.

James Pearson Howes is a free-lance photographer based in the London, who uses a strong reportage style of portraiture. 

Self published, 2012

40 pages
15 x 20 cm
full colour
Signed copies
Edition of 250

name: Hate Mail by Mr Bingo
description:
Mr Bingo loves post but was worried that people don't get enough 'fun' post these days. Especially postcards. So he began a project where he invited people to send him some £'s and he sent them a vintage postcard with a little drawing and an offensive message on it. This is a collection of some of those postcards. And hilarious it is too.

'Gorgeous and funny! Like a labrador doing stand-up' - Noel Fielding

Beware, it contains some explicit content.

208 pages
19.5 x 14 cm
full colour

name: Somatic Archaeology by Daniel Blumberg
description:
A collection of drawings in biro and crayon, by Daniel Blumberg (Yuck, Oupa and Hebronix) done between April and May 2012

Published by Boiled Egg, 2013

32 pages 
14 x 19 cm 
full colour 
hand sewn,hand stamped
Signed edition of 100

name: Counter-Print Issue 10
description:
Counter-Print (which was known as Eight:48 up until issue 8) is a quarterly publication looking at design. 

The tenth edition of 'Counter-Print' consists of two papers. Paper #01 focuses on the art and design of bookshop ephemera, while Paper #02, entitled ‘New Work’, offers a snap shot of some of the best work we've had sent to us from the design community over the past quarter.

56 pages
29 x 40 cm
full colour on newsprint

name: Day Job - issue 1, Manufacture
description:
Day Job is a publication for anyone who has ever had a job they've loved, a job they've hated, a life-long calling or a way to make an easy buck. In short, it's about work, a celebration of the everyday ways in which we spend our time and energy. As the inimitable Studs Terkel describes working, "It's about a search, too, for daily meaning as well as daily bread, for recognition as well as cash." Published in New York.

Includes: Courtney Sheet Metal Works, Gregg Monsees, Street Food NYC, Milton Glaser & Steve Hindy, Working Outdoors, Bjorn Engdahl, New York Farm Show, Samir Sayegh, Barber Seats, Our Legacy, Catherine Breton, Aesthetics of Productivity, How to Teach a Math Problem and more...

192 pages
16.5 x 24 cm
full colour

name: Life Size by Sam Falls
description:
An astounding amount of work has been included in this beautiful book. Full of colour and often playful, this is a collection of photographs of the day to day life and work of LA artist and photographer Sam Falls.

Published by Karma, 2012

322 pages
30 x 23 cm
Softcover
Full colour
Edition of 1000

ISBN 9781938560057

name: Little Joe Issue 4
description:
Little Joe is a unique forum for the discussion of film around subjects of sexuality and gender within a queer historical context. Since launching our first issue in 2010, the magazine has quickly become an important place for stimulating dialogues on film, leading the way in queer analysis of cinema and providing a platform to celebrate films that inspire alternative discourse. 

Film curator Bradford Nordeen pays tribute to transgender punk icon Jayne Country and the stars of City of Lost Souls, Rosa von Praunheim’s underseen and over-the-top Berlin musical.  Interviews with legendary underground filmmaker Mike Kuchar by artist Johnny Ray Huston, former Hole drummer Patty Schemel by A.L. Steiner, Swedish filmmakers Ester Martin Bergsmark and Eli Levén talk to Tomas Hemstad about She Male Snails, Helen de Witt meets the irrepressible provocateur Charles Lum. Author and activist Sarah Schulman selects her Video Library, Ron Gregg examines Barbara Rubin’s role in the New York Underground, Jon Davies expresses his adoration for Miss Edmonton Teen Burger 1983, Marc Siegel provides us with a humorous discussion of the work of R. W. Fassbinder and Liz Rosenfeld gives a personal account of queer filmmaking in modern Berlin. Our regular Visual and Other Pleasures section includes contributions from Keep the Lights On director Ira Sachs, Ultra Culture’s Charlie Lyne, academic and author Douglas Crimp and Semiotext(e) editor Hedi El Kholti plus archive material from Vito Russo and an excerpt from Myra Breckinridge’s Cookbook. The issue also includes a special pull-out comic book by Mike Kuchar.

144 pages
138 x 216 mm 
one colour riso printed

name: A Visit - Part I: Photographs by Nigel Peake
description:
Published Analogue Books
Numbered ltd. edition of 100
A5, 28 Pages, b&w
Hand-printed Gocco cover. 

Photographs by Nigel Peake from visits to New York and San Francisco.

name: Føroyar by Elmar Bambach
description:
Elmar Bambach lives and works as a photographer in Berlin and Leipzig. He is co-editor of  and co-founder of Ein Magazine über Orte and co-founder of Bücher & Hefte.

The Faroe Islands are located in the North Atlantic, midway between Norway, Iceland and Scotland. On 18 islands are about 48,000 people and twice as many sheep as the name already suggests - Føroyar translates as  Sheep Islands.  Approximately 5000 people play football on the islands. They play where ever there is space in the harsh landscape, and if you kick the ball with enough power over the goal, it will land in the Atlantic.

Published by Bücher & Hefte, 2012

48 pages
21 x 15 cm
coftcover
Colour offset
German language
Edition of 400

ISBN 9783981453034

name: Symbolical Visions by Daniel Johnston
description:
Symbolical Visions was published on the occasion of an exhibition of the same title, of the drawings of Daniel Johnston, shown at La Casa Encenddida, Madrid in April 2012. The drawings are the personal collection of Jeff Tartakov, Johnston's former manager. 

His drawings reflect on his unique, creative universe full of characters taken from comics and North American culture - the exhibition was an attempt to analyse the meaning of these drawings. 

146 pages
16 x 23.5 cm
full colour
soft cover
in Spanish and English

name: Sketchbook - Blue Birds, designed by Bjorn Rune Lie
description:
100% environmentally friendly sketchbooks from Nobrow, with awesome cover design by Bjorn Rune Lie. His idiosyncratic  designs are inspired by natural history journals, printed in spot colours on a beautiful heavyweight cover stock. Inside are 128 pages of the very best Munken Pure (FSC) off-white paper that is as much of a pleasure to touch as it is to draw on. The lovely rounded corners also make it easy for you to slip them into your pocket or bag without getting them all dog eared.

128 pages
17 x 24 cm
colour cover, plain paper inside
Softcover

name: Made Quarterly edition one
description:
MADE focuses on inspirational people from around the world who create incredible things, including but not limited to industrial design, architecture, fashion, interior design, photography and the culinary world. MADE aims to get inside the heads of those individuals to find out how they do what they do, and what inspires them to create. Each issue will take a peek behind the scenes and offer the reader a rare opportunity to glimpse inside the minds of these inspiring individuals.

The premiere edition of MADE Quarterly features: Nendo (JPN), Aulik Fiser Architects (CZE), Dinosaur Designs (AUS), Feit (AUS), Alt Group (NZL), Form Us With Love (SWE), Wrenchmonkees (DNK), Katie Quinn Davies (AUS), Patterns From Above (USA), and Noe Duchaufour-Lawrance (FRA).

Size: 96pp 200mm x 260mm
Production: 4 colour process plus 1 PMS
Cover Stock: Various—300gsm Textured Coated Stock
Internal Stock: 64 Pages 120gsm Uncoated Stock 
and 32 Pages 120gsm Coated Stock

name: A Dictionary of Colour Combinations
description:
Re-stocking, available again soon

An amazing book which is based on a 6-volume work by Haishoku Soukan published in Japan in 1933. 

It contains 348 colour combinations organised by Sanzo Wada, who laid the foundations of contemporary colour research.

354 pages
15 x 11 cm
Full colour
Japanese language

ISBN: 9784861522475

name: Romka Magazine Issue 7
description: Romka began as an online magazine 4 years ago and has since  grown into a very handsome printed version, based in Leipzig. It's a beautiful magazine devoted to personal favourite photographs, pictures that really matter: the print from your fridge, the portrait you keep on your desk at work, pictures of places you love. Pictures of great sentimental value that gain their quality through the personal experiences they are connected to and not through form or content. It is not about your best pictures, but about your personal favourites. Photographs included are from all over the world, from professionals and amateurs.

name: Variations on Normal by Dominic Wilcox
description:
Re-stocking, available again soon

Dominic Wilcox is an artist, designer, inventor and ‘thinkeruper’ who works within the territory of the ‘everyday’. He is based in London and has exhibited internationally -including here in our shop! Many of these drawings were originally shown in his exhibition here, so it's great to see them collected together in this book.

'I have put together over one hundred of my odd yet strangely logical invention drawings into a little book. They all come from a room inside my head that I like to go to every now and again' - Dominic Wilcox

‘Dominic Wilcox’s drawings aren’t just witty and beautifully drawn, they are serious challenges to the real world to keep looking at itself with innocent eyes, wondering what else is possible' - Thomas Heatherwick

104 pages
12.5 x 12.5 cm
full colour
Edition of 1000
Each book is signed

name: A Visit - Part II: Photographs by Nigel Peake
description:
Published Analogue Books
Numbered ltd. edition of 100
A5, 28 Pages, b&w
Hand-printed Gocco cover. 

Photographs by Nigel Peake from a visit to Shanghai.

name: Islands No 2 by Brendan Monroe
description:
This is the second, almost wordless, story of Brendan Monroe's wandering, dream-based comics. A couple explore the deep sea floor and the gravitational relationship of moon and tide. The drawings are beautiful and it's a lovely large format.

Self published, 2012

24 pages
28 x 30 cm
Metallic copper ink on black paper cover, inside pages are black ink on a light gray recycled paper

name: Smokes & Mirror by Ross Fraser McLean
description:
Published by Analogue Books
Signed and numbered ltd. edition of 50
44 pages
A4, 297mm x 210mm
Hand-sewn binding

In the summer of 2011 photographer Ross Fraser McLean travelled to India with a plan to travel the length and breadth of the country. He wanted to experience their diverse culture, the cities, the countryside, the desert land. However, a snap decision made on the day he arrived saw him stranded in a tiny village in the middle of nowhere, a virtual captive of the Sapera Caste of North India - a mysterious and dwindling community who have been living on the extreme fringes of society since their proud tradition of Snake Charming was outlawed by the Indian Government.

A new publication of photographs documenting Ross's experience.
Features an essay by Anthropologist Dr Jane Hartley

name: Snowfall Kingdom by Yule Bringer
description:
A tale of trippy, festive woodland folks by our favourite wizard, Yule Binger/Adam Higton. An insane amount of work has gone into this large format comic. 

Published by Gnome Books, 2012 

16 pages
21 x 30 cm
b&w
Numbered edition of 200 copies

name: Here and There 11 - Nakako Hayashi
description:
Nakako Hayashi was editor for Shiseido’s culture magazine Hanatsubaki before leaving to become a freelance editor and writer for Ryoku Tsushin and Purple Journal, amongst other international publications. Since 2002 Nakako has created her own independent magazine Here and There - a genuinely personal creation, co art-directed with and designed by her long-time friend Kazunari Hattori. It is produced as a record of her time, her friends and the events around her that she felt were too important to be left undocumented.

In this issue:

Elein Fleiss and her new found life
On Vulnerability - A Conversation with Pascale Gatzen
Susan Cianciolo -Incomprehensive Beauty 
Ryoko Aoki Reading Kiyoshi Oka 
IMA KOKO
Nakako Hayashi On the IMA KOKO ISSUE 
Takehito Koganezawa, Two Reports
Aoi Nagae - A Change 
Erika Kobayashi - A story of Mothers
Suiren Higashino - The Small Sprout
Ryoko Aoki - To Know You Are
Kei Takemura - dearest unknown You
Yukinori Maeda - Blueprint for Mandara Architectur 
Gerda Steiner & Jorg Lenzlinger - Power Sources
Nakako Hayashi - A Transient Hope

64 Pages
21 x 30 cm
Colour Offset
Bilingual Japanese/English

ISBN 978-3-905999-10-5

name: CLUB DONNY Issue # 9
description:
CLUB DONNY is a biannual magazine on the personal experience of nature in the urban environment. 

Developed in 2008 by three Rotterdam-based Dutch editors, Club Donny is a global survey of the ways in which urban living intersects with the nature. Readers are invited to join the club by submitting their own work online and becoming participants in the conversation.

In this issue:

Yeb Wiersma, David Leda, Frank Bruggeman, Elias Tielman, Jan Van Adrichem, Welkin Ji, Talina van der Hoeven, Stephan van Vliet, Maarten Feenstra, Petrovsky and Ramone, Marcel van der Meijs, Wouter Sibum, Wilfred Nijhof, Annick Kleizen, Ben Cohen, Yasuyuki Takagi, Bert de Jong

36 pages
21 x 30 cm
full colour
loose leaf to provide 14 posters

name: Underscore Issue 4: The Flight Issue
description:
Underscore is an independent magazine based in Singapore, with thematic content attuned to a simple rhythm; quality of life. Conceived to underline/highlight simple values that are important but neglected in our everyday lives. A carefully selected soundtrack accompanies every issue to complete the reading experience.

This issue explores all aspects of flight, from NASA missions to slack-lining, birds’ nests to circus acrobats as well as a DIY cardboard aeroplane cut out, designed by Jaime Hayon

Contributors include: 

Illustration by Jaime Hayon
Photography by Jan Kempenaers, Leonardo Pellegatta, Sharon Beals, Tsuneaki Hiramatsu
Writing by Annelie Bruijn, Carly Jayne, Hamish Robertson, Hannes Früh, Hila Shachar, Jerry Bonnell, John Sarkissian, Kai Von Rabenau, Lilia Rusterholtz, Nathan Williams, Naz Sahin, Omar Sosa, Robert Nemiroff, Roy Poh, Ryan Gander, Sam Bleakley, Serifcan Ozcan, Steve R Plant, Thierry Legault, Thomas Mader, Tim Moore

144 pages
18 x 26 cm
full colour

name: Etapes Magazine Issue # 29
description:
Etapes is a design and visual culture magazine featuring the best articles from its French sister publication, étapes:international.

In this issue:
A brief overview of the European Design Awards with Eve Chabanon and Charles Loyer, Isabelle Moisy and Eve Chabanon look at the publicity created for some of the many cultural and artistic festivals over summer, we meet Geoff McFetridge, Interviews with: Ostengruppe, Cox & Grusenmeyer, Cobbenhagen Hendriksen, Jan & Randoald, Emily King takes a fresh look at Richard Hollis, Robin Kinross on Modern Typography 20 years after it was first published, Barney Bubbles, the Asymmetric Harmony of Karel Teige, the history of Freitag, comment and book reviews and more...

144 pages
20.5 x 27 cm
Full colour

name: Hector - Issue 2
description:
Hector is the second periodical published by East London menswear establishment Hostem. Each issue is named after a different man and therefore takes on an altered persona. His predecessor was the more delicate Sebastian, the two are not to be mistaken as allies. 

Hector is an erudite activist concerned with arts, politics, and parity.  This publication bares itself with a defaced poster, a documentation of the French presidential campaign by artist Pascal Fellonnea.

Between the pages Hector journeys just outside Rome, to meet Maurizo Amadei from atelier design house ma+. Then to Prizendorf castle, Northern Austria, where Hermann Nitsch communicates his fixation with controlled violence.

For visual stimulation Blommers/Schumm entertain with physiological illusions. And artist Koen Hauser collaborates with collage artist Ruth van Beek, which results in a clandestine fashion shoot. Photographer David Moore captures delicate images of various ‘apparatus of the state’. Should this not suffice the Chapman Brothers’ dominant critic-Julian Stallabrass remains scathing of the YBA art movement, and the remarkably private worlds of London’s members clubs are exposed.

112 pages
24 x 30 cm
full colour

name: The Colour Chart of Deep Thought by The Lindström Effect
description:
Another excellent publication from The Lindström Effect - The Colour Chart of Deep Thought features some of our greatest thinkers represented in colour. 

'Painting your Living Room? why not not try Jean Paul Satre's Being Autumn, Existential bathrooms, Absurdism bedrooms. Find your colour philosophy here. But please tread carefully down the dark Freudian hallway.'

14 pages
14 x 21cm
full colour
hand-stitched binding

name: Finger aus Licht by Sabina Baumann
description:
Sabina Baumann’s large pencil drawings are detailed, richly laden with symbols: the peace sign appears again and again. Against the brick wall a wagonwheel loses its spokes and thus also becomes a peace symbol, but more than that, this wheel in its old-fashioned appearance contributes to an anachronism that stands for the parallel worlds that are combined in Baumann’s images. 

Baumann is based in Zurich, Switzerland.

Published by Nieves, 2012

24 Pages
14 x 20 cm
b/w
Edition of 150

name: Diary by Jessica Williams
description:
Diary is a collection of lush abstract ink compositions that meditate on being, internal space, and travelling. With only a brush, water, and India ink, Jessica Williams articulates this through her malleable shapes, deep blacks and heavy, wet gestures. It is as if each drawing is an attempt to clear the mind of each and evey thought until only a singular smooth surface remains. All of the drawings were made over a number of months in the artist's Oslo studio in calm periods between a rigurous schedule of traveling both within Norway and outside in Europe, Asia, and Africa.

Jessica Williams is an American artist currently based in Oslo, Norway.  She has self-published a handful of zines, exhibited all over the world. Since 2011 she has run a small press called NSEW (North, South, East, West) and the Self-Publishing Workshop at the Oslo National Academy of the Arts.

Published by Nieves, 2012

20 Pages
14 x 20 cm
b/w 
Edition of 150

name: Dank Magazine Issue No 3
description:
Dank is an independent skateboard magazine from Oslo, Norway. The magazine was founded in 2010 by three friends brought together by a shared passion for skateboarding and print media.

Dank no.3 features interviews with Magnus Bordewick, Stian Bakke, Jake Johnson, Norwegian movie director Joachim Trier, skateboard videographer Jørgen Johannessen, photographer Sergej Vutuc, and Pontus Alv of Polar Skateboards. The third issue also features pictures from Greg Hunt's "Selective Memory" retrospective, plus an exclusive series of Deerman of Dark Woods shot by Alana Paterson. 

Dank is written in Norwegian but now comes with a supplement made exclusively for international readers, featuring English translations of all the stories.

128 pages
21 x 28 cm
full colour

Was £10 - Now £5

name: Collisions by Brendan Monroe
description:
This zine is full of drawings inspired by data from the Large Hadron Collider at CERN in Switzerland - the world's largest particle accelerator that is probing our deepest understanding of the universe by testing what happens when particles collide at nearly light speed.  

Self published, 2012

14 pages
14 x 10 cm
B/W
soft cover
stitched binding

name: Ploc - Issue 2
description:
PLOC Magazine is the happy magazine for little ones. Illustrated by the legendary artist Alain Grée, designed & published by the good people behind Anorak Magazine.

PLOC Magazine is aimed at children aged between 3 and 8 years old but the beautiful illustrations mean anyone can enjoy it.

This isssue has SPORT as it's theme, looking at lots of different kinds of sports, through puzzles, games and colouring in and all illustrated by the amazing Alain Grée. 

48 pages
17 x 21 cm
full colour

name: Remain in Balance by Steven Harrington
description:
In this book, Harrington attempts to shed light on the universal struggle of staying balanced in a Life that is continually changing without our consent. Together with words by Elena Harrington, Steven’s series of Totem drawings started merely as pencil sketches that he began doing during his down time at his home in LA. Playing with the idea of the Linear, both vertical and horizontal, he recognized that his "balance drawings" and the objects that they were comprised of revealed a merge between his personal and professional life, that these Totem Poles, similar to what they have historically done for centuries, told a story. Here Steven’s first release for Nieves also functions as a catalogue of sorts for his first solo artshow August 2012 in Los Angeles California.
 
Cited as leading a contemporary Californian psychedelic-pop aesthetic, the Los Angeles-based artist and designer Steven Harrington is best known for his hazy hued, iconic style that encourages a two way conversation between the artist and viewer. 

Elena Harrington, former Editor for DASH Literary Journal and creative writer, finds depth of words and their meaning in the clear and concise. Elena resides in Long Beach, California, where she seeks inspiration in the eclectic lifestyle creating wire wrapped, antique, and asymmetrical designed Jewelry.

Published by Nieves, 2012

36 Pages 
19.5 x 25.5 cm 
Softcover
First Edition
 
ISBN 978-3-905999-07-5

name: Kerim in the Sky with Seiler by Kerim Seiler
description:
From the Nieves website:

'In the mid-nineties, Kerim Seiler paints Zurich city furnishings on found pieces of fiberboard. Chosen workaday design serves as ready-to-paint object and is protocoled in pictograms. Seiler's paintings dissolve into single elements turning three-dimensional. His work becomes walkable and can be viewed from behind. One stands within the picture, "inside of the outside", so to speak. Perspicuity and practicability lend Seiler's work the claim of social sculpture, without depending on fundamental contentions. Through flexibility and humor, the sculptures emit an integrative quality. The work of Kerim Seiler is always on the road and sometimes the guest of nice people'
A.C. Kupper 

Edited by Patrick Huber and Kerim Seiler, text by Adrian Notz, Bettina Malcomess

Published by Nieves, 2012

3 Volumes in Jacket
each 96 pages
16.8 x 23.7 cm
Hardcover
Colour Offset
First Edition

name: Things by Nigel Peake
description:
'Things. Objects and Fragments.'

Partially drawn while artist in residence at the Salzamt in Linz, Austria earlier this year this zine is a collection of drawings about groups, gatherings and isolated things. 

Self-published June 2012

32 pages
14.5 x 21 cm
2 colour litho print 
Soft cover 
Saddle stitch

name: I'll Kick You in the Head with My Energy Legs by Jonnie Craig
description:
I'll Kick You In The Head... depicts the everyday life of a group of skateboarders from London. Each person helps to build momentum in the picture story, whether it be walking along the Thames sludge-covered beaches in search of an American friend who had an "emergency shit" after accidentally drinking a bottle of laxatives, a trip to the hospital to fix a dislocated elbow, or playing with a dead pigeon. 

The photos were taken over three years by photographer Jonnie Craig. He had his breakthrough when he was only 18 being picked up by Vice Magazine. 

Published by Dokument Press, 2012

112 pages
23.5 x 30 cm
hardbound, cloth cover
b&w, 84 photographs

ISBN: 9185639516

name: Yaw Kabe Part One by Dominic Kesterton
description:
Dominic Kesterton is one busy chap - currently studying Illustration at Edinburgh College of Art, he also makes music as Zefs Chasing Cara, is one half of the excellent Edinburgh-based print press Workhorse as well as producing a neat line in zines.

Yaw Kabe is the 1st instalment of a strange tale where the main character is visited in his dreams by 'Yaw Kabe' and sets off on a new journey. Or something. 

Beautifully simple and unsettling drawings, with some amazing patterns, Yaw Kabe is large format and riso printed. Pretty special. 

24 pages
20 x 28.5 cm
2 colour - blue and black riso print

name: Our Garden Birds by Matt Sewell
description:
'A bird for every week of the year'.

We've had the pleasure of knowing Matt for years and are proud to have hosted 2 of his exhibitions so we're very pleased to see his first book arrive. An enthusiasm for birds and nature has always featured heavily in Matt’s work and this book presents his beautiful water colour illustrations of 52 of our favourite garden birds. The accompanying descriptions and observations bring the characters of each bird to life and make this less of a serious guide and more of a loving salute to our feathered friends.

Published by Ebury, 2012

128 pages
14 x 19 cm
full colour
hard cover

name: HOUSE WEAR issue 1
description:
HOUSE WEAR was initially a multidisciplinary exhibition which was part of the 2011 State of Design Festival in Melbourne. Like the exhibition, issue 1 of HOUSE WEAR addresses the condition of impermanence in everyday life and its effect on contemporary design. Artists, writers, architects and designers explore how this relationship affects the way we live, and the impact of nomadic behavior on our perception of house/home.
 
Contributors include Dylan Martorell, Ash Kilmartin, ffiXXed, Sibling, tin&ed, Adelle Mills, Nicholas Nicholas, Anna MacKenzie, Sophia Mitchell, Yahna Fookes, WORTHIS, Beata Wilczek, Sri Spong, New Friends and MANY MANY.


70 pages
14.5 x 20 cm
full colour

name: Final Bargain by Peter Sutherland
description:
Peter Sutherland is a NYC based artist who works in different mediums producing thought provoking imagery in a non-indexical manner. His work is a reflection on life as a young American, on fragments of urban degradation and exposes the happy accidents that make life interesting.

Co-Published by Nieves and Innen, 2012


28 Pages
14 x 20 cm
b/w Offset
Edition of 500

name: Aaron / Benjamin by Shoboshobo
description:
Shoboshobo aka Mehdi Hercberg is a Paris based artist. His work involves a wide range of projects including illustration, graphic artworks, clothes design, music and printed editions. His graphic work is mainly focused on monsters and creatures that are strange, pop, frightening and sometimes cute. He has performed and exhibited in several countries. In particular, he has a strong bond with Japan, where he visits as often as he can. 

C0-published by Nieves and Innen, 2012

		Aaron / Benjamin
Shoboshobo (Paris, France)

Shoboshobo aka Mehdi Hercberg is a Paris based artist. His work involves a wide range of projects including illustration, graphic artworks, clothes design, music and printed editions. His graphic work is mainly focused 

look inside

56 Pages
14 x 20 cm
b/w Offset
Edition of 500

name: Greenhouse Studies by Philippe Weisbecker
description:
Born in 1942, Weisbecker studied interior design in Paris. By 1968 he moved to New York. First working as a draftsman in an architectural firm, he started a career as an illustrator at the age of 30. His work has been published in major american publications such as the New York Times, Time magazine and The New Yorker among others. In the late 90's he shifted gradually from commissioned work to his own original production which he is now showing in galleries worldwide. 

Weisbecker's art consists of depicting elements of our daily life untouched by the sometime devastating effects of fashion's changing mood. These range from tools to appliances, industrial buildings to public housing and, greenhouses. Greenhouses were created for the purpose of preserving an inner world from the outside world. They haven't changed much over time. Their purpose created their form. There lies their eternal beauty. It is this beauty that Weisbecker invites us to share with him through his Greenhouses study book. 

Published by Nieves, 2012

32 Pages
16 x 22.5 cm
Colour Offset
First Edition

name: Le Rose, La Couleur Des Hippies by Hayan Kam Nakache & Josse Bailly
description:
Hayan and Josse are two big nosed, big footed artists from Geneva. They like the hippie and post hippie culture and decided to make drawings together about it and have fun and a laugh. They say they were trying to be very stupid, and feel like stoned freaks, as Elbert Hubbard said: "Genius may have its limitations, but stupidity is not thus handicapped." The drawings have a simple quality to them and many depict jokes by the two artists.

Published by Nieves, 2012

20 Pages
14 x 20 cm
b/w Photocopy
Edition of 100

name: My Heart Also Has Preference by Jen Uman
description:
My Heart Also Has Preference is a selection of drawings where artist Jen Uman's personal experiences merge with Indian cinema, Middle Eastern culture, and infatuations. The result is 20 carnal, soft, and unfamiliar pages made with gouache, a pen and markers.

Published by Nieves, 2012

20 Pages
14 x 20 cm
b/w Photocopy
Edition of 100

name: Cardigan Heart by Lizzy Stewart
description:
A very lovely book of short, illustrated stories and snippets of life, written and drawn by Lizzy Stewart. Some stories are just a page, others cover a couple of spreads. Beautiful stuff.

28 pages
15 x 21cm
full colour, litho printed 
soft cover

name: Seesaw Fidgets by Evah Fan
description:
A new zine from the brilliant Evah Fan. We've loved Evah's work for years now, her small, delicate, and humorous, drawings. 

In this book of droodles (apparently an old 1950's name for a combination of doodles, drawings and riddles) Evah presents a super simple line drawing on one page and tells you what it is discreetly over the page. Of course the fun is in working it out. 

48 pages
13.5 x 18.5 cm 
One colour
printed offset with soy-based ink on recycled paper

name: Gloaming by Keaton Henson
description:
Gloaming is a beautiful, dreamlike graphic novel by the artist/musician Keaton Henson. The book’s concept is essentially a field guide to a spirit world beyond our reality. Its melancholic narrative shows spirits that are lost in the city, lonely and seeking escape. As a result they move to the countryside but find they are still lost, so consequently decide to leave the planet, which in turn is but another creature continually searching for something it cannot find.

Keaton’s inspiration is born from old Scandinavian folklore and Japanese Kwaidan (ghost stories) from the Edo period, to the more contemporary Miyasaki Spirited Away films.

Keaton's music is pretty sweet too, look him up here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BZPnlMfMOzY

Published by Pocko, 2012

112 pages
21 x 15 cm
Hardcover
b/w inside, colour cover

ISBN: 9781903977378

name: The Commuter screen print by Rebecca J Kaye
description:
The Commuter is a beautifully simple, four-colour screenprint by Edinburgh-based illustrator and cyclist, Rebecca J Kaye.

Hand printed, signed & numbered on 270gsm GF Smith Paper. 
A conservation standard mount is included with each print.

Limited Edition of 50

Dimensions
Inside mount: 177 x 177mm
Outside mount: 230 x 230 mm

name: Pedal Power screen print by Rebecca J Kaye
description:
Pedal Power is a beautifully simple, three-colour screenprint by Edinburgh-based illustrator and cyclist, Rebecca J Kaye.

Hand printed, signed & numbered on 270gsm GF Smith Paper. 
A conservation standard mount is included with each print.

Limited edition of 50.

Dimensions 
Inside mount: 210mm x 290mm 
Outside mount: 300mm x 400mm

name: Le Velo screen print by Rebecca J Kaye
description:
Le Velo is a beautifully simple, three-colour screenprint by Edinburgh-based illustrator and cyclist, Rebecca J Kaye.

Hand printed, signed & numbered on 270gsm GF Smith Paper. 
A conservation standard mount is included with each print.

Limited Edition of 100

Dimensions
Inside mount: 177 x 177mm
Outside mount: 230 x 230 mm

name: Goliath by Tom Gauld
description:
We're very excited by Tom's new book, he really is a master at storytelling. His apparently simple drawings manage to convey atmosphere, tension and humour to perfection. Here he reworks the story of David and Goliath. 

Goliath of Gath isn’t much of a fighter. Given half a choice, he’d pick admin work over patrolling in a heartbeat, to say nothing of his distaste for engaging in combat. Nonetheless, at the behest of the king, he finds himself issuing a twice-daily challenge to the Israelites: "Choose a man. Let him come to me that we may fight. If he be able to kill me, then we shall be your servants. But if I kill him, then you shall be our servants." 

Published by Drawn and Quarterly

96 pages
25 x 17.5 cm
Hard cover
Two colour

ISBN: 9781770460652

name: In The Wilds: Drawings by Nigel Peake
description:
A beautiful hardback book from the most excellent Mr Nigel Peake. 

Featuring almost 100 original drawings, a charming collection of Nigels handdrawn observations of rural life. From trees, fields, lakes and rolling hills that form the country landscape to the farmhouses, sheds, tractors and fences that define it, Nigels obsessively detailed pencil and ink drawings and beautifully muted watercolours capture the slow-moving rhythm of his surroundings.

Published by Princeton Architectural Press 2011
 
15.2 x 20.3 cm
Hardcover 
136 pages
80 colour illustrations, 18 b/w illustrations 

ISBN 9781568989525

name: Hose Variations by Bjarne Bare
description:
Hose Variations is the first book by Bjarne Bare. This monograph, as the title suggests, consists of studies of hose variations. It is a study of time in between human interaction, where the dead moment, rather than the decisive, is in focus. The surroundings and placement of each hose reveal their owners character and is a light anthropological study of man, as well as a take on the traditional documentary genre of photography. It consists of Bares recent work from Berlin, Buenos Aires, Lodz, Los Angeles, and Oslo.

Published by Cornerkiosk Press, 2011 

40 pages
26 x 19cm
Softcover
Four Colour Offset
First Edition of 500

ISBN 978-82-998640-0-8

name: De Profundis by James Jarvis
description:
James Jarvis unveils his first new narrative in five years. This highly anticipated graphic novel follows an artist who travels through a wilderness to arrive at an abandoned city. Wandering the empty streets there, he encounters a mysterious, priestly being who commissions him to decorate a temple to nameless gods.  

Jarvis is well known for his collectable Amos vinyl figures and his excellent 'Onwards'   animation. This book might be considered a departure from Jarvis' previous projects; here, he has constructed a personal narrative with artwork that combines his interest in medieval woodcuts and Dutch De Stjil.

64 pages
21 x 28.5 cm
Full colour
Hardcover

name: Quality of Life - Brian W. Ferry
description:
Edinburgh-based Lawson's Books present their first book Quality Of Life, a collection of photographs by Brian W. Ferry. Brian is an American-born, self-taught photographer currently residing in London, UK. He has contributed work to publications from other independent publishers such as Lines & Shapes and Kinfolk Magazine, as well as completing commissions for the likes of Starbucks and Ralph Lauren.

The images included in Quality Of Life were pulled from the vast quantity of photographs that Brian took between January 2010 and January 2011, his first year living in London. Many of them were first shared on his popular blog The Blue Hour, and neatly encapsulate what he has said sums up the nature of his work: a desire to document the small and often seemingly unexceptional moments of day to day life, capturing these quietly beautiful details and making visual diary entries, allowing us to dwell on them with him.

First Edition of 500 copies
167x215mm / 48 pages / 37 colour images
Soft cover, perfect bound
ISBN 978-0-9570378-0-9

name: Ein Magazin über Orte # 9
description:
Ein Magazin über Orte (A Magazine about Places) is published twice a year. It deals with a different location in every issue, collecting works of various authors in the form of photographs, drawings and texts.

No.9 is about Berlin. At first glance the focus of the magazine is not on the people living there, but rather on the city’s urban landscapes and small scenarios. In more than 70 works by artists like Rainer Fetting, Carsten Kaufhold or Amelie von Wulffen, by photographers like Sibylle Bergemann, Axel Hütte, Arwed Messmer or Juergen Teller, and in poems and short texts by authors like Jürgen Becker, Kerstin Hensel, Durs Grünbein or Lutz Seiler, different perspectives on the metropolis Berlin in its constant changes and transitions appear without glorifying it.

84 Pages
21 x 27 cm
Colour Offset
Edition of 4000
Text in English & German
2011

name: Robert Samuel Hanson: 140 Colour Images
description:
Robert is an old friend and we've had the joy of working with him a few times over the years so it's great to see a whole book of his beautiful work. Amazing stuff.

This book features 140 colour illustrations, organised into groups according to their subject matter. These illustrations are accompanied by an interview with the illustrator about his work, life and accomplishments.

Robert is a Berlin-based freelance illustrator who has worked for clients such as The New York Times, Monocle, Google, Wired and The Royal Mail among others.

This is the first monograph published by Counter-Print. 

Please note there are 2 different covers for this book, if you have a preference please contact us.

160 pages
15 x 21cm
Softcover
Designed by Leterme Dowling and published by Counter-Print, 2011
Comes with Book Mark

ISBN: 978057081604

name: Bangkok - Shanghai by Stefan Marx
description:
Bangkok - Shanghai is the eighth in a series of travel zines Stefan has done for Nives. 

On his visit to Thailand and China, Stefan Marx drew visual notes and sketches of people and the many passangers on the flights from Shanghai, with a stop in Bangkok back to Germany, paying particular attention to their hairstyles and distinct fashions and presenting them as individual portraits.

Published by Nieves, 2012

28 Pages
14 x 20 cm
b/w Photocopy
Edition of 150

name: Cocoa and Coconuts by Massimiliano Bomba
description:
Skillfully using cocoa, coconut shells, rubber bands and plastic, Jim and Matt have created, over the years, marvelous sculptures around the world. This is one of their sketchbooks, exclusively shown for Nieves.

In 2006, Massimiliano Bomba founded his own small publishing house RawRaw Edizioni, releasing a selection of publications and editions focusing on the contemporary.

Published by Nieves, 2012

20 pages
14 x 20 cm
b/w Photocopy
Edition of 150

name: REAL TIME by Nous Vous
description:
Nous Vous is a the massively talented multi-discilinary art and design studio based between London and Leeds. They work as a collective and as individuals - Nicolas Burrows, Jay Cover and William Edmonds. 

Museums Press present this lovely 3 part zine of their recent work - Nicolas Burrows' zine "Plague Diaries" contains a series of double page spreads, contrasted mark making at its best . Jay Cover bases his zine, "Limbo", on Finisterrae by Sergio Caballero with a set of delicate and sparce pencil goodness. Finally, "Holiday" by Willam Edmonds is a sort of travel diary (in the loosest sense) of a trip to Malmo, Sweden. 

Released on the occasion of "Real Time", an exhibition of works by Nicolas Burrows, Jay Cover and William Edmonds at Good Press.

Published by Museums Press, Decembeer 2011

3 zines
each one 12 pages
14 x 20 cm
staple-bound
black & white digital print
wrapped by a title band
edition of 50

name: Faker Drinker Soldier Heiress by Clunie Reid
description:
Drawing on imagery from advertising, the internet, magazines and her own drawings and photographs, Clunie Reid’s photo-collages appropriate and violently represent the banality of everyday images. Drawing on the sexual content and rhetoric of advertising, and often reproduced on a mirrored surface with hand-scrawled jokes and texts overlaying them, the images play on the relationship between surface and penetration, where distorted images, words and text shatter the reflection of the mirrored surface.

In this artists’ book these illusionistic, sexual games are replayed across the blacked or mirrored surface of the pages. Using images, jokes, text, and drawings, the book becomes a hall of mirrors in which one meaning rapidly collapses in on itself only to reproduce a new multifaceted one.

Published by Bookworks, 2010

64 pages
20 x 29 cm
full colour, with two spot colours and flood printed UV varnish throughout
Soft, mirrorboard cover
Edition of 1,000 copies

ISBN: 978 1 906012 26 7

name: Allerseelen by Alexander Binder
description:
Morel's second book from Alexander Binder brings together a phantasmagoria of mystical  images, seamlessly blending crystal rainbows with even the most arcane and dark twilights, constructing a world of haunting beauty and mysticism.

Alexander Binder was born on Halloween night 1976 in the Black Forest/Germany. He is a self taught photographer, having never attended a photo class in his life. Even his lenses are mostly self built from optical toys, old soviet cameras, prisms or bits of plastic. A fan of Hans Bellmer and Herbert List, Alexander creates mystical and ethereal photos which are characterized by a strong passion for the spiritual, the surreal and the occult.

Published by Mörel Books, 2011

48 Pages 
22 X 31 cm 
Full colour
Soft cover
Limited Edition of 500
     
ISBN: 9781907071300

name: Some British Birds by Edwyn Collins
description:
Scottish Indie musician legend Edwyn Collins illustrated these spellbinding birds on a daily basis after suffering two cerebral hemorrhages in 2005.

The delicacy of the birds demonstrate Edwyn’s skill as an illustrator while under the constrains of using his left hand, having lost control of his right after the strokes.

The illustrations chart his unrelenting endeavor to recover.

Published by Morel Books, 2009

72 Pages 
29.7 X 21 cm 
B/W
Soft cover
Edition of 1000

ISBN: 9781907071072

name: Some Approaching End by Jaakko Pallasvuo
description:
Some Approaching End is Jaakko Pallasvuo’s second comic book and his debut in English. The story follows two young adults, driven by romantic ideals, on a quest to become less confused. Their encounters with the supernatural both complicate things and drive them along. Irreversible transformations lie ahead. The dense, pencil-drawn panels are beautifully reproduced in a saturated riso-blue.

Published by Landfill Editions, 2011

48 Pages 
10 x 27 cm 
2 Colour Risograph & Silkscreen Cover 
1 Colour Risograph Interior 
Saddle Stitched 
Edition of 250

name: Fire By Days by Rita Ackermann
description:
'For a year now, she said that all she keeps making are these paintings called Fire by Days. Swelling forms, always in red and blue. This is a quest. The artist is summoning the form up from deep within'.

'In these paintings, there are mystical-erotic motifs that present the essence of the artist as a performer of her work. There is a conduit for the flow of energy that propels us into the unknown and mysterious, and one has to dig in deep to find the language to speak about these works, that don’t care if they might look like they could represent something to someone' - Rob Weiner

Published by Nieves, 2011

20 Pages
19.5 x 25.5 cm
Color Offset
First Edition

name: Nigel Peake 'Maps' Book
description:
"The drawings in this book are an edited collection from the past few years.

Documenting small time adventures and excursions outwith a mile radius from where I call home. From train rides facing backwards, to crammed bus rides in tiny hill-top towns, to bike rides through the backyards of Europe. Records of the vast, unyielding concrete miles of Shanghai, to the paths between mountains and forests in late night French countryside to the old paint splattered wooden floor in London that I sleep on from time to time. In addition to this there are also some imaginings of possible places - cities built from train tunnels and underground arches to invisible concrete cities.

Some of the maps are drawn a couple of months after the occasion and others begin as a scribble in thin card-covered sketchbooks in desolate airports on overnight waits. The drawings are of the micro and the macro, the colourful and the monotone, the fragments and the nearing complete."

About Nigel Peake
Nigel Peake is a former RIBA silver award commended architecture student from the University of Edinburgh, where he has also tutored and assisted in the design units. Last year a collection of his work was published as 'Sheds.'

From his attic studio on a quiet road he continues to enjoy making and drawing things. He has recently exhibited in Antwerp, Shanghai, Philadelphia and Los Angeles and his drawings have been used for a variety of commercial projects.

See more of Nigel's work at http://www.secondstreet.co.uk

32pp
148.5mm X 210mm
SOFTCOVER
FULL COLOUR
PERFECT BOUND
ISBN: 9780955628412

name: Bicycle Travel Journal: Illustrated by Nigel Peake
description:
This journal encourages us to take up travelling by bike – on short or long rides, through urban, suburban or rural areas, along roads, coasts and mountain paths – and record these colourful journeys. Nigel Peake's beautiful drawings map out ideas and guide riders through new landscapes, both real and imaginary. With 20 illustrations, blank pages to write on and 4 envelopes to store mementoes of your journeys.

128 pages
136 x 199 mm
Soft cover

ISBN: 9781856699006

name: DIY Furniture: A Step by Step Guide
description:
Featuring 30 designs by leading designer-makers from around the world, DIY Furniture shows you how to use simple techniques to make stunning designer furniture from scratch. 

Along with designs for seating and storage, the book also features projects for making your own bed, wardrobe, lighting and garden furniture. Each project features hand-drawn diagrams with short, easy-to-follow instructions on how to build the piece.

All the projects can be easily assembled using common materials to be found at the local hardware store, allowing the reader to create unique designer pieces at a fraction of the normal cost. Brief biographies of all the featured designers are included at the end of the book.

Published by Laurence King, 2011

144 pages
24.5 x 21 cm
Paperback
Full colour
270 illustrations

ISBN 978 1 85669 742 2

name: Midwest: Photographs by Tom Cops
description:
Restocking - available again soon

In August 2010, artist and musician Tom Cops  travelled around the American Midwest for three weeks with his  band, supporting the acclaimed Minnesotan blues musician Charlie Parr. 

During the tour, Tom attempted to photograph everyone he met, and places they passed through, looking for odd details in the landscape.

In his foreword to Midwest, Charlie Parr recollects:  
“Crossing the rocky mountains, stopping in grand old living ghost-towns like Butte, Montana and Lusk, Wyoming. Tom took photographs of the few people and buildings there, both seeming weathered hard by the constant wind and standing like tombstones, still, serious and sparse for Tom's camera.

He stopped them all; middle-aged bartenders, tourists, punk-rockers, hippies, very old and very young, me, my mom, my daughter, my wife, my son, all of us got stopped in time by Tom’s camera, a kind of living graveyard.” 

This record of their journey is divided into States, with watercolour chapter pages by Jerwood Drawing Prize nominated artist Aaron Sewards.

Published by Betty and Dupree, 2011


72 pages
24 x 17 cm
Perfect bound, soft cover,

name: Yule Bringer: Sledding In The Cosmic Neighbourhood
description:
A 6 Track CDr by everybodys favourite wizard, Yule Bringer/Adam Higton, accompanied by a set of 6 lino prints, each by a different artist and based on a track from the album.

1. Glow
2. Mushroom
3. Flying On A Leaf
4. Black Cat
5. Sledding In The Cosmic Neighbourhood
6. Forest House

Prints by Sophie Kern, Adam Higton, Jake Blanchard, Simon Peplow, Eleni Kalorkoti & Marcus Oakley

Edition of 100 copies

Published by Tor Press

name: On Vient Quand Même! by Gil Pellaton
description:
Table bombs, ice cream and balls of lights in nebulous doom and gloom: Artist Gil Pellaton places his grotesquely twisted figures in imaginary scenes that hover between scenery-like reality and bizarre exaggeration. The large-scale oil paintings are dynamic and as specific as dreamlike worlds can be. On Vient Quand Meme! is his inaugural publication, combining his most recent works in a small but mighty volume.

Pellaton (1982) lives and works in Bienne, Switzerland. His work was honored with the Anderfuhren Recognition Price in 2009 and the Swiss Art Awards 2010 - Kiefer Hablitzel Price. He exhibited at the Journal Gallery in New York and the Grand Palais in Bern. 

Published by Nieves, 2011

20 Pages
19.5 x 25.5 cm
Colour Offset
First Edition

name: All About: Crystals Nous Vous • Super/Collider
description:
From crystal caves and ancient rituals to transistors and terrorists, CRYSTALS lurk everywhere – even outer space. Find out what makes a crystal grow, why they were worshiped and where to find the world’s largest specimens in this illustrated guide.

All About: Science is a new series from Landfill Editions and super/collider, exploring the myriad worlds of science through the eyes of contemporary image makers.

Words – Chris Hatherill
Illustration – Nicholas Burrows & William Edmonds
Design – Hugh Frost

Published by Landfill Editions, 2011

12 Pages 
15 x 20 cm
2 Colour Risograph & Silkscreen Cover 
2 Colour Risograph Interior 
Saddle Stitched 
Published 2011 
Edition of 150

name: Conversations on the Coast by Nick Hand
description:
Re-stocking - available again soon

Conversations on the Coast presents a selection of 20 stories and photography from the Slowcoast project.
 
Graphic Designer and Photographer Nick Hand set off on his bicycle from Bristol in the summer of 2009 to cycle over 6000 miles around the coast of the British Isles. The people he talked to along the way included weavers, boat builders, a stickmaker, bicycle mechanic, screen printer, cheese maker and tea taster. 

Conversations were recorded and edited as photofilms and uploaded from the saddle to the Slowcoast website, giving followers of the journey the chance to meet an inspirational group of people living and working around the coast of England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland.

Included in the book:

Kay Anderson, Spinner
Bill Bontoft, Stickmaker
Austin Brown, Bicycle Mechanic
Will Brown, Outfitter
Merin Crossingham, Animator
Sheena Devitt, Stone Letter Carver
Martin Doyle, Flute Maker
Laurence Edwards, Sculptor
Douglas Grierson, Weaver
John Joseph Hanna, Hat Maker
Joanne B Kaar, Paper Maker
Paul F Kelly, Gold and Silversmith
Nigel Legee, Fisherman and Artist
Dominique Lieb, Letterpress Printer
Joanne Mitchell, Glass Maker
Kiera Rathbone, Typewriter Artist
John J Savage, Storyteller
Peter Segger, Organic Farmer
Pat Tanner, Boat Builder
Pip Weaser, Basket Maker

For more info on Slowcoast visit www.http://slowcoast.co.uk/

96 pages
14 x 17.5 cm
Hardback
Full colour
Published by The Department of Small Works, September 2011

£1.00 from the sale of each book will be donated to Parkinson's UK. 


ISBN: 9780956933201

name: Behind Every Curtain by Marcel Dzama
description:
This is a beautiful catalogue. It was published on the occasion of the artist's sixth solo exhibition at David Zwirner in 2011. The exhibition debuts a major new film, A Game of Chess, alongside related drawings, sculptures, and dioramas. 

In the film, characters based on the classic game of chess, dressed in geometrically designed costumes and wearing elaborate masks, dance across a checkered board to challenge their opponents in fatal interchanges. Designed in collaboration with the artist in the format of a small sketchbook, this exhibition catalogue includes drawings, storyboards, dioramas, and film and production stills from the making of A Game of Chess. 

Published by David Zwirner, 2011 

80 pages
15.5 x 20 cm
softcover
full colour

name: The Dead Sea by Stefan Marx
description:
With his debut release on co-owned Smallville record label Stefan Marx presents an exclusive three-part poster collection coated inside a gatefold 12-inch cover sleeve. Giving the Smallville shop and label a visual face since the very beginning Stefan Marx created hundreds of posters and flyers, painted the shop windows regularly and conceived every single record cover.

Now it's time for himself to release an extraordinary Smallville/Nieves issue in 12-inch format. Three folded posters (each 90 x 60 cm) including a first appearance of his Band project The Dead Sea (aka Stefan Marx, RVDS, Lawrence and Birte Löschenkohl).

Published by Nieves/Smallville, 2011


3 Posters in Gatefold Record Sleeve
60 x 90 cm
b/w colour Offset
Edition of 500

name: The Group of Ten by Supermundane
description:
"Recently I have been seeing faces in drawings that I find each morning."

The Group of Ten is a short story about a man who finds a new painting on his kitchen table each day with no idea how it got there. In these paintings he recognises something he can take as being life.

Numbered limited edition of 200 with hand-painted, signed and stamped face painting. (due to these being originals they will differ from the ones show) 

20 page story zine, with 10 illustrated pages
14.5 x 21 cm

name: Billboards by Nigel Peake
description:
Inspired by his travels around France in 2009, Nigel has produced this beautiful book of imagined billboards for a French town.

name: Iskandariyah Skan by Ingo Giezendanner
description:
"My previous picture book was about a train trip to Baku, this book documents my ferry trip accross the Mediterranean Sea to Alexandria (or Iskandariyah as it is called in Arabic). I was invited to exhbit my work and conduct a workshop organized by the artist-run Alexandria Contemporary Arts Forum (ACAF). This paperback is a selection of the many drawings that transpired on this amazing journey.

Not all my drawings are of a scene that catches my eye. Often it starts with coming across a really comfortable spot where I can sit undisturbed for some time amongst the hustle and rumble of a busy city. This, for me, can be quite meditative. Later, I scan the drawings to upload onto my website and other applications.

This time round, I also experimented with the drawings and hope to present this book as my personal development or work in progress. I wish to share the overwhelming experience of drawing the ocean and have tried to capture the simultaneous static second and fluid element of the water by flushing the drawings through a scanner and allowing them to distort as they wish to flow, much like the city, much like life itself."

Ingo Giezendanner alias GRRRR, July 2011

Since 1998, Ingo Giezendanner documents his surroundings with pen on paper. He produces zines, murals, books, exhibitions, video clips and maintains a website (GRRRR.net) to create his own world.

Published by Nieves, 2011

192 Pages
13.2 x 18 cm
Soft Cover
b/w Offset 
First Edition

A brilliant collection of scribbles, poetry and very short stories from the lovely Ewan John - anyone who likes Spike Milligan or Ivor Cutler will enjoy this.

www.ewanjohn.com

name: News by Jürg Lehni & Alex Rich
description:
The Speed-i-Jet, a mobile pen-printer manufactured by Reiner (Germany), is a device built around an industrial inkjet cartridge / printing head. With its clumsy user interface and 30 character maximum capacity, this charming parasitical product prompted the discussion of possible uses for such a device. Together with the curatorial staff of the institution, daily news headlines were selected and transferred onto the devices. Holding and moving the device like a pen, visitors could experience the writing of texts to which the author is ambiguous.

The headlines were collected during Things to Say at Kunst Halle Sankt Gallen, Switzerland, 2009. 

Published by Nieves, 2011

You can watch the Speed-i-jet demo here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zzJOoE28Q6Q

24 Pages
19.5 x 25.5 cm

name: Diary of an Egg Collector by Edward Summerton/Graham Fagen
description:
A collection of entries from Graham Fagen's egg collecting diary from 1969 - 2007, each page tells which kind of egg was collected, sometimes with a note of how it was obtained or a headline or event from that date. On the other side of the page is a beautiful painting of the egg collected, to scale, by Edward Summerton. 
 
Published to coincide with Edward Summerton's exhibition Warm Leveret at the Shetland Museum.

96 pages
9.5 x 14 cm
full colour
soft cover

name: A Curious Catalogue by Michael Leon
description:
A Curious Catalogue is a skateboard product catalogue of pencil drawn anti-graphics, spin-art wheels, and slalom gemstones. It was designed to take a romantic and fantastic vision of a skateboard company and make it ‘real’. Michael Leon was inspired by the naïve wonder he experienced as a young skateboarder, which he juxtaposes with an elegant, yet dry, catalogue sales format. The result is a carefree and poetic narrative carried by a range of imagined products.

Michael Leon was raised in late 80's, early 90's skateboard culture. His work lives in a unique place between the worlds of art and art direction. He often uses the language of graphic design to create meaning through sculpture, paintings, videos, and editions. While still in high school, Michael designed his first pro model skateboard for New Deal Skateboards. 19 years later, he continues to design for his skateboard company Stacks, as well as creating artwork and art directing collaborative projects. 

Published by Nieves

19.5 x 25.5 cm
Colour Offset

name: More With Less - Stephen Smith, Neasden Control Centre
description:
Under the motto 'More with Less', a playful variation on the well-known modernistic principle of 'less is more', Steven Smith created an overwhelming visual world by which he aims to examine and lay bare the essence of our fully automated communication.

Published by MU

32 pages
19.5 x 25.5 cm
full colour 
softcover

ISBN 978-90-79423-06-4

name: Everything Flowers - Clare Rojas
description:
Collected here for the first time are the beautiful and exotic paintings of Clare Rojas. One of the San Francisco Bay Area's most beloved art stars, Rojas is influenced by craft, folk art, and the beauty and wisdom of the garden. Her work weaves together flowers, plants, animals, and various folk figures to create mysterious narratives. Through the language of flowers—delicate yet resilient, powerful yet flexible—Rojas tells enchanting stories with color.

Clare Rojas is a multimedia artist known for her painting, installation, film, printmaking, quilting, and music. Her work has been featured in numerous exhibitions around the world. She lives in San Francisco, California



By Clare Rojas
Foreword by Natasha Boas
6 x 8 in; 96 pp ; 4-color illustrations throughout
Hardcover
Published by Chronicle Books

name: No More Pie in the Sky by Beni Bischof
description:
"No More Pie in the Sky is a thrilling, bloody but funny zine about confused people in necrophobia." A sense of humor and a humble understanding of the world around artist Beni Bischof flows effortlessly between paintings, drawings, collages, prints, sculpture and installation. 

Bischof’s ability to allow each work to shine independently is rooted in his confidence to possibly make mistakes and his ability to approach each day with an honest approach to his varied process of art making. 

Published by Nieves, 2011

28 Pages
14 x 20 cm
b/w Photocopy
Edition of 150

name: Vanishing Memories by Samuli Blatter
description:
Vanishing Memories is the beginning of an experimental process that revolves around the perception of the world and its phenomenon of the fragmented structure and their decay and reconstruction. Vanishing fragments which tend to disappear, to evolve, to erode and to get restructured by them who remind at.

The work of Samuli Blatter currently focuses on researching drawing as a medium and material, a tool for chains of thoughts, imaginary travels and a system to work simultaeously to build a net of images correlating among themselves and oscillate between grammatical construction and intuitive gesture. 

Published by Nieves, 2011

4 Pages
14 x 20 cm
b/w Photocopy 
Edition of 150

name: Dondoro by Estelle Hanania
description:
Dondoro is a photographic work born from the collaboration between Estelle Hanania and the famous Japanese puppet master Hoichi Okamoto. 

Okamoto is an enigmatic creator who lived alone in the Japanese countryside near Nagano, creating hundreds of puppets for his own performances. He archived all his puppets since the late 1970s. When Okamoto slips behind one of his human-sized puppets to animate it, a confused game began between the master, the puppet and the photographer. 

Estelle Hanania is a Paris-based photographer with a background in graphic design, art direction and fine art. She graduated in 2006 from the Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Beaux-Arts de Paris and, in the same year, won the ‘best photographer’ prize at the highly prestigious Hyeres Festival in Southern France. 
Her photography has been exhibited in several galleries and her work, both commissioned and personal, has appeared in magazines including Another, 032c, Vice,Capricious and more.

As usual with Estelle Hanania’s work, Dondoro leads the spectator into a world where human figures constantly appear and disappear, in the magical world of a magical storyteller.

Published by Kaugummi, February 2011

 
48 pages

name: Wrong by Asger Carlsen
description:
“Based on a true story” Asger Carlsen’s series is a haunting and disturbing perspective of the everyday.

In some cases subtly surreal and in other blatantly blasted with a dystopian hallucinations, the series is visionary and original. By employing a traditional black and white palette, Wrong peers past reality into a parallel existence.

The series is more than appropriate during a time in which there has been lobbying and calls to label beguilingly photoshopped advertorials with warnings. Through using the same mechanisms and tools of the trade, Wrong has broken through the looking-glass into a parallel visual culture, opposing our present perception of hyper-reality and constructed beauty.

Dark and humorous, the absurdity and distortion of Wrong is a satirical travesty of photographic culture as the ultimate simulator and the simulacrum.

Published by Morel 

88 Pages
22 X 22cm
Two different covers - one white and one black
Foreword by Tim Barber

Edition 1000

name: Barry McGee
description:
Barry Mcgee's art celebrates the rich pageant of city living, while lambasting its "ills, overstimulations, frustrations, addictions." This book includes his photographs, drawings, paintings and documentation of past and present installations.

His early years as a graffiti artist, tagging on the streets of San Francisco under such monikers as Ray Fong, Twist and Twisto, still nourish his need to inscribe the blank face of modern life with the personal and the handmade. McGee synthesizes a wide range of resources, including the Mexican muralists, anonymous street art and San Francisco Beat poetry, all of which are notably characterized by a sense of public address that McGee never neglects to convey in his own work. His paintings, drawings and installations spill over with graphic energy and political anger, and direct exhortations to his audience to respond to the life around them. 

Barry McGee was born in San Francisco in 1968 and studied at the San Francisco Art Institute. He continues to live and work in that city. He has had solo exhibitions at Brandeis University's Rose Art Museum in Waltham, Massachusetts, Deitch Projects in New York and the Prada Foundation in Milan amongst others.

204 pages
Hardback

ISBN: 9788862080965

FIELD NOTES set of three 48-page memo books

name: People by Marcus Oakley
description:
People is a compendium of pencil portraits by Marcus Oakley of his good friends, close family members and some interesting strangers. 

The drawings are based on archive of two years worth of photographs taken in public and private – from visits to friends houses or on rural picnicking excursions, bicycling jaunts and nights out at gigs or down the pub.

These informal and impromptu images add up to a meandering visual essay on the subject of portraiture. While the images on the pages of 'People' work as likenesses and evocations of the character and moods of their sitters; these portraits are filtered through the artists personal and distinctive graphic style. 

Cumulatively, while People presents us with a cavalcade of individuals, each persons distinctive features and style are synthesised into a quirky visual grammar 

20 Pages
14 x 20 cm
b/w Photocopy

2010

Published by Nieves

description:

name: French 'Boar Tree' Screen Print
description:
Three colour, 50cm x 70 cm
Hand printed on archival, acid free 200gsm white Heritage paper
signed and numbered edition of 50

About Early Griffin Press
'We set up Early Griffin as a project to enable us to indulge our love for the hand made quality and process involved in screen printing and the desire to work with artists we admire.'

'We work closely with invited artists to produce a series of screen prints in limited editions of 50, with 3 artists in each series. Each print is editioned by us by hand and individually approved by the artist. We hope we can work with artists at all stages of their career and from all corners of the globe.'

Early Griffin donates 10% of the profits of each edition to a charity of the artist's choice.

About French
French's `Boar Tree' seems to take inspiration from mediaeval woodcuts and manages to be beautiful and twisted at the same time. It's warm green and brown are set off perfectly by the amazingly detailed black line work.

French hails from Aldershot, a part of the UK known for its Army Base - a good place to start an interest in torn body parts. An obsession with Metal music informs his work that literally draws the line between the magnificent and the repulsive. His sensitive and detailed line work show's beauty in the revolting.

French's recent clients include Pointer, Carhart, Uniqlo and Slam City and he has exhibited widely across the globe.

French would like 10% of the profits of this print to go to L.O.S.T., a charity that helps and supports those affected by solvent abuse.

Related Links
http://www.tapedcopies.com
http://www.earlygriffin.com

name: Rita Ackermann-Marfa/Crash parking accidents

Marfa/Crash
Rita Ackermann (New York, USA)

32 Pages, Tabloid 26 x 38 cm, Color b/w Offset, First Edition, 2009

WAS £17.95, NOW £9.95

name: Cody Hudson: Save My Life
description:
Cody Hudson is a Chicago based painter, also known for his commercial art and graphic design contributions under the name Struggle Inc. Known for the production of clean, multi-dimensional graphics, Cody's design aesthetic is part urban modernism, and part organic visual deconstruction. His graphic work and paintings have been exhibited throughout the US, Europe and Japan including the Museum of Contemporary Art (Chicago), Rocket Gallery (Tokyo), The Reed Space (NYC), The Lazy Dog (Paris), & Bucket Rider Gallery (Chicago). "Save My Life" focuses on every aspect of Hudson’s prolific career, including graphic design, painting, printmaking and sculptural installation.

Fifty24SF Gallery
96 pages
Hardcover

name: Jan Kruse Screen Print
description:
Jan Kruse for Early Griffin Press Series 4

Three colour, 50cm x 70 cm
Hand printed on archival, acid free 200gsm white Heritage paper
signed and numbered edition of 50

About Early Griffin Press
'We set up Early Griffin as a project to enable us to indulge our love for the hand made quality and process involved in screen printing and the desire to work with artists we admire.'

'We work closely with invited artists to produce a series of screen prints in limited editions of 50, with 3 artists in each series. Each print is editioned by us by hand and individually approved by the artist. We hope we can work with artists at all stages of their career and from all corners of the globe.'

Early Griffin donates 10% of the profits of each edition to a charity of the artist's choice.

About Jan Kruse
Jan’s image is chock full of his signature happy faces, little creatures and rainbows building a better world for us. His style is almost guaranteed to make you happy. This one is 3 colours, green, purple and black.

Jan Kruse is co-founder and one-third of the huge talent that is the Human Empire, a graphic design and illustration studio based in Hamburg. Their clients come from industries like fashion, music, art and advertising. They are perhaps best known for the beautiful Morr Music artwork and also, over the last couple of years, their own line in tee shirts and other lovely things available through their own stores, also in Hamburg.

10% of the profits of the sales of Jan’s print will go to a charity of Jan’s choice, tbc.
